column3: Leader (first among equals),Deliberation,Corporal punishment/Violence against perpetrator,Self-help,Mediation,Negotiation,Exit,Criticism/Mocking/Joking,Reputational risk,Suspension/Expulsion/Ostracism/Proscription,Tribunal/Court ,Meritocracy
column5:
Hxaro - System of mutual reciprocity and social responsibility established to hedge the whole group against risk and pool resources (hxaro)

'Each family creates ties which distribute its risk over the population and thereby assure that losses will be covered in bad years.' (Wiessner (1982), p. 66)

'The hxaro relationship involves a balanced, delayed exchange of gifts, whose continuous flow gives both partners information about the underlying status of the relationship - one of a bond of a friendship accompanied by mutual reciprocity and access to resources. In addition, each partnership links a person to a broad network of hxaro paths' (Wiessner (1982), p. 66)

'Among the Ju/'hoansi, punishment typically does not take place through witchcraft, financial reparations, socially sanctioned duels, or violent retribution. Rather, most punishment takes place in conversations, or at least it begins as talk' (Wiessner 2005 p. 121)

'Punishment was divided into four categories: (a) put-downs through pantomime, joking, or mocking, (b) mild criticism and complaint, (c) harsh criticism or complaints, and (d) criticism plus violent acts' (p. 122)

Both men and women initiated criticisms and punished others

Ostracism for women who developed relations with Bantu men

Retaliation against perpetrators went from mocking and joking to harsh criticisms and violence

Culture (from Wiessner 2005):
''Strong reciprocity occurs when individuals are willing "to sacrifice resources for rewarding fair and punishing unfair behavior, even if this is costly and provides neither present nor future rewards for the reciprocator" (Fehr, Fischbacher, and Gachter 2002:3).' (Wiessner (2004), p. 116)'

'Strong reciprocity requires high levels of monitoring within the group and subsequent action to bring individual behavior in line through reward and punishment.' (p. 116)

'Foragers live in cooperative communities where food is shared widely and children are reared by a range of "alloparents" from grandparents to siblings (Draper 1976; Hewlett 2001; Hrdy 1999; Konner 1975). Widespread food sharing prevails within the community (camp), reducing variance in subsistence income, supporting those who are not capable of providing their own food at certain points in their lives, and promoting cooperation' (p. 117)

'Egalitarian relations (Boehm I993, 1996, 1999; Cashdan 1980; Clastres 1977; Gardner 1991; Kelly 1995) are maintained among foragers to facilitate reciprocity and cooperation on five accounts (Wiessner 2002a). (a) They standardize certain information by specifying that all adult members of the society are autonomous equals who cannot command, bully, coerce, or indebt others. (b) They reduce the risks of cooperation because people do not fear that assistance given in the present will be used to dominate in the future. (c) They stipulate that it is the obligation of all people to stand up for their interests and permit all individuals to punish norm defectors, if they choose to do so. (d) They allow individuals and families to choose different options when environmental conditions require dispersal. (e) They facilitate mobility between visiting groups because hierarchies do not mesh easily. Egalitarian institutions vary in how encompassing they are, that is, whether they include adults of both sexes and all ages, and whether equality applies to both opportunity and outcome (Flanagan 1989; Robbins 1994). For the Ju/'hoansi, as for many foragers, equality applies to all adults and to equality of opportunity as well as equality of outcome.' (p. 117)

column169:
Headman. According to Lee, headmen become more prominent upon contact with British colonizers and black settlers. Headmen are often elders and have other personal qualities that distinguish them. But they have no formal authority. 

The figure of the headman changes dramatically when incorporated into the Botswana state
column170: leader of the community, heads the kgotla

column169:
Court

Led by the headman. introduced upon contact with the Batswana. enables dispute resolution beyond feuding. this is a late development, dating to the late 1940s

column3: Election,Council (central) ,Assembly (central),Magistrate/official,Balance of power,Ratification/Acclamation only
column5:
There are many Celtic oppida throughout norther Europe (central/north France, Switzerland and Germany west of the Rhine). They are organized along tribal lines, with inter-tribal institutional links of which we know relatively little (intermarriage and clientelism for defense are possible). Most of the evidence for political institutions comes from the Aedui, one of the tribes written about by Caesar. 

that of the Aedui is an interesting case because they seem to have had assemblies but we only know that they auctioned the right to farm a tax.

no direct information about size, but we have some figures from Caesar about other tribes (p. 235) and the population was probably larger than the greek city states (p. 237)

"there were defined rules surrounding the eligibility of candidates for magistracies aimed at preventing control by a supreme ruler or family." (p. 238) [the author, however, does not specify such rules]
column11: Collis, “Celtic” Oppida, in Hansen, A Comparative Study of Thirty City-State Cultures
column169: Controlling body among the Aedui. No information available about membership or size.

column11:
Main: 
Kammerer, Cornelia Ann (1985/86), Gateway to the Akha World: Kinship, Ritual and Community among Highlanders of Thailand; Ph.D. Dissertation Anthropology, University of Chicago

Discovered through: 
"James C. Scott, The Art of Not Being Governed" Footnote:
"Turton, Andrew, Civility and Savagery: Social Identity in Thai States (2000)" p. 144
column12: Informal inclusion,Gender groups,Informal power imbalance
column169:
Person with the highest authority in the village.
Responsible for:
-	Founding villages, initiating yearly household-based ancestor offerings, officiating at annual communal rites, adjudicating intravillage disputes, fining those who transgress Customs (e.g. adulterers) (Lewis 1968b; 1969-70:128-134) (Kammerer, p. 90-91)
-	The ceremonies led by the Village Founder-Leader primarily concern the welfare of the entire community. (Kammerer, p. 103)

"lead" rather than "rule":
-	A better translation for “dzo” is “to lead” (Kammerer, p. 93)
-	It is his duty to follow Customs; he cannot impose his individual will upon villagers in his care (Kammerer, p. 93)

Requirements:
-	Must uphold Customs. However, expert knowledge of oral tradition and ritual procedures is not a prerequisite for office. (Kammerer, p. 95)
-	Must be “pure” or “clean”: his wife cannot have been pregnant at the time of their marriage and together they cannot ever have produced twins or deformed children. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	A man must give up his position if he is no longer “clean”. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	Qualifications: he is calm, impartial, and sincere man willing to listen to others who are better versed in the intricacies of Customs. (Kammerer, p. 95)

Succession: 
-	The office is not necessarily inherited. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	A son, usually the youngest who remains behind in his parents’ household after his older brothers have established independent households, often succeeds his deceased father. 
-	Such succession, must however, be ratified by the male elders. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	Male heads of families planning to form a new community may jointly nominate one among themselves or recruit another respected “clean” man to select the site and serves as Village Founder-Leader. (Kammerer, p. 94)

Extra:
-	The Village Founder-Leader’s life thus differs little from that of his neighbours, even though he is respected by virtue of his office. (Kammerer, p. 95)
-	The first house built (usually near the centre of the settlement) must be his (Grunfeld 1982:54; Lewis 1969-70:125-128; Lewis and Lewis 1984: 218) (Kammerer, p. 90)
-	“If there is no Founder-Leader (dzoma), a village cannot be built” (Kammerer, p. 90)
column170:
Council of Elders:
-	Although dzoma does arbitrate disputes and impose fines, he does not do so alone. (p. 93)
-	Rather he does so in consultation with other male elders; his decision legitimises the consensus reached (p. 93)

column169:
There were 4 types of Assistant Founder-Leaders:
-	1) The son of the Village Founder Leader
-	2) Selected by male elders in communities in which he had previously lived. His father had been an Assistant Village Founder-Leader.
-	3) Selected by male elders in communities in which he had previously lived. His father had not been an Assistant Village Founder-Leader.
-	4) Chosen by the community’s male elders. This man’s paternal grandfather had served as a Village Founder-Leader, but his father had not.

column169:
Blacksmith (baji in everyday speech; ciqma in the archaic oral tradition)
-	Position is restricted to men (p. 98)
-	Not automatically hereditary. Nonetheless, the craft is often taught by an older to a younger relative. (p. 98)
-	It is not necessary for a Blacksmith to be “clean” (p. 99)
-	Within a community there may be more than one Blacksmith. (p. 99)

column169:
A religious officer trained in ritual texts of the oral tradition and responsible for ceremonies that concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit.
Some of his roles:
-	The elaborate funeral ceremony for an adult in which the Reciter’s chanting guides the deceased to the above of the ancestors (Hanks 1974; Hanson 1983) (p. 103)
-	Leads the various purification rites following a “bad death” (p. 103)
-	Enact ceremonies to re-establish order after the birth of twins or a malformed child. (p. 103)
-	Nevertheless, neither birth nor marriage rituals are his province. (p. 104)

-	Recitation of the ritual texts of the oral tradition is the essence of the office. (p. 100)
-	To become a Reciter a man must study with one or more Reciters. (p. 100)
-	During his apprenticeship he is known as p’iza “Apprentice Reciter”. (p. 100-101)
-	This position is achieved rather than inherited. (p. 101)
-	Requisitions: “clean” man who has the intelligence and perseverance required to memorise the vast corpus of ritual chants (p. 101)
-	He must provide his mentor with liquor and stipulated gifts, including a set of new clothes. (p. 101)
-	Although the office is not inherited, many men are taught by a patrilineal relative. In such cases the customary payment from a student to his teacher is not required. (p. 101)
-	Even a young Reciter spends few days, if any, working in his family’s fields. (p. 101)
-	Ceremonies led by the Reciter primarily concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit. 9p. 103)
-	The Reciter, unlike the Village Founder-Leader, has no official role in rituals of the annual cycle. (p. 103)
-	Although villagers prefer to have at least one Reciter among them, a community need not have a resident Reciter. (p. 103)
column170: Division of labour: whilst the Village Founder-Leader is concerned with rituals of the annual cycle, Reciter leads ceremonies that primarily concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit.

column169:
A representative of the Akha people in Thailand's National government
-	His job is to act as liaison between government officials and villagers (p. 110)
-	Functionary in the national government system (p. 109)
-	Does not have to be “clean” (p. 110)
-	Receives a small monthly stipend from the District Office (amphur) for his services (p. 110)
-	He is obligated to attend regularly scheduled meetings at the District Office (p. 110)
-	Is the person contacted by various officials (e.g. field representatives of the Hill Tribe Welfare Division of the Department of Public Welfare, Ministry of the Interior (p. 110)
-	Maximum of 5 cycles. (p. 110)
-	Permitted to vote: those who have both a national identity card and a house registration card issued by the District Office (p. 110)
column170: The representative in the National government

column12: Informal inclusion,Gender groups,Informal power imbalance
column169:
A female official with ritual responsibilities that may partake in decision-making indirectly from behind the scenes.
-	Through her ritual responsibilities links annual ancestor offerings and yearly rice rituals. (p. 116)
-	Although she has no official say in village decision-making, her position is respected, and she may exert substantial influence behind the scenes, especially if she has a strong personality and has reached venerable age (p. 117)

column12: Informal inclusion,Gender groups,Informal power imbalance
column169:
A council with the highest power in the village.
-	Some ethnographic accounts report that village disputes are settled by a “council of elders” (for example, Lewis and Lewis 1984:227).
-	Kammerer prefers to avoid this phrase because it conveys what she considers to be a false impression of formality, rigidity, and corporateness. (Kammerer, p. 118)
-	Every male head of patrilineal family should attend meetings called by the Village Founder-Leader. (Kammerer, p. 118)
-	Full attendance may not be realised, and an old man may well send a son in his stead.
-	Issues are discussed until a consensus is reached, and his consensus is validated by the Village Founder-Leader (Kammerer, p. 118-p. 119) 
-	Elders sit at the esteemed downslope tables at ceremonial meals. (Kammerer, p. 119)
-	Women and men are invited independently to these meals (p. 119)
-	A man may have sat at a men’s downslope tables for years before his wife is asked to sit at a women’s downslope table for the first time. (Kammerer, p. 119).
-	(abo and ap’i).
column170: Council of Elders discuss issues, and their consensus is validated by the Village Founder-Leader

column12: Informal inclusion,Gender groups,Informal power imbalance
column169:
A gifted person shosen by spirits that identifies cures for illnesses in her dreams.
-	Chosen by spirits (p. 118)
-	Being “not clean” does not prevent spirits from selecting an individual as a sama (p. 118)
-	The sama’s insight into curing is obtained in dreams rather than during travels in trance. (p. 118)
-	Curers of both sorts are usually adept at setting broken bones and knowledgeable about medical plants. (p. 118)

column12: Informal inclusion,Gender groups,Informal power imbalance
column169:
A gifted person chosen by spirits that identifies the cause of the illness through entering trance to the world of the ancestors.
-       Open to both men and women (Kammerer, p. 117)
-	Enter trance to the world of the ancestors to seek aid in finding lost souls of the sick or in identifying the agents causing illness and the type of rituals needed to appease them. (p. 117)
-	The Shaman’s job thus overlaps with that of the Reciter. (p. 117)
-	Many communities do not have a resident Shaman (p. 118)
-	Shaman is chosen by spirits. (p. 118)
-	Potentially not necessary to be “clean” (p. 118)

column11:
Camera, M. Istoria della città e costiera di Amalfi in due parti divisa

Schiavo, A. Amalfi: profilo storico

Kreutz, B.M. Before the Normans: Southern Italy in the Ninth and Tenth Centuries (the Middle Ages Series)
column169:
Annual magistracy (board), each figure operates in a different period but covering roughly the same tasks. Elected by the popular assembly. Often filled by heredity.

Camera, M. p. 70 ("Amalfi (…) veniva governata da un Pretore, o Epata, come i Greci lo chiamavano ed era immediatamente dipendente e sommessa al Duca, Console, o Maestro de Soldati di Napoli") | Camera, M. p. 89 ("eligendosi dapprima i Prefetti annuali, poi i Conti e poscia i Dogi, i quali non erano principi assoluti o ereditari, ma bensì elettivi della repubblica, e che governando con pieno potere si sceglievano dal corpo della nobiltà") | Camera, M. p. 111 ("Poco soddisfatti gli Amalfitani del sistema di governo de loro Prefetti e Conti, e quasi annojati per lo spazio di 42 anni da quella magistratura, si dettero premura d'innalzarla a più orrevole grado con l'eligervi di Dogi") | Camera, M. p 111, nota 1 ("Doge, così detto per distinzione de duchi feudatari. Gli amalfitani non soggetti a' principi Longobardi, non solo non conobbero i feudi al pari de' Greci a cui ubbidivano; ma anche altre leggi non regnarono presso loro, salvo che quelle dominanti fra greci al pari delle altre città non soggette a' Longobardi")

Camera, M. p 89 ("Noi però colla scorta di tutte le nostre cronache possiamo francamente affermare che l'elezione de' nostri Dogi dipendeva dall'assoluto consenso del popolo e de' nobili tal quale eseguisvasi in Venezia; e tal volta si succedevano i parenti più prossimi")

column3: Consensus,Oath,Handshake,Leader (first among equals),Consultation
column5:
Nomadic Bedouin society governed by rulers selected (not hereditary) who ruled through consultation - shura (Stasavage 166-7). There is no explicit evidence of consultative bodies, or the mechs presiding over their functioning.

In Islamic times, Shura is a method of reaching consensus about leader selection. Islamic evidence and pre-Islamic conjecture is discussed in Crone's article, esp. pp. 14 ff. "As the only alternative to fragmentation, consensus was the overriding aim of communal life: it was what shura was supposed to bring about." (Crone p. 15).

column3: President/Consul/Chief Executive,Assembly (central),Assembly (elite),Constitution,Voting,Majority voting,Remunerated position,Tribunal/Court ,Bureaucracy
column5:
Independent city-state. Constitutional monarchy in which the king is the steward of the God Assur and the head of the city assembly (which is really a council). There the king has one vote. 

Assur population: Larsen, p. 79

the constitution is the set of written rules regulating the functions of the city-assembly, like voting. "The assembly is to be divided into voting blocks in order to reach a majority decision. All of these activities were supervised by the scribe or secretary of the Port, clearly a salaried official." p 84

Like Emar, Tuttul and Sippar, Assur has a "republican government." The database only includes Assur and Sippar.
column11: Larsen, M. T. The Old Assyrian City-State in Hansen. M.H. A Comparative Study of Thirty City-States Cultures
column169:
King, chief executive of the community

Assur's king held two titles: Isshiak Assur, or “Divine Assur’s steward” (the emphasis is on “the divinely sanctioned role as head of the community and as chief priest”) and Waklum, or “Leader” (the emphasis on its role as the implementer of judicial decisions taken by the city-assembly)

City assembly, central political and judicial institution of the community, it was composed by the elders and notables of Assur. It could be divided and set into special committees to look into especially complex cases, including audits and financial transactions. judicial functions.

"The assembly is to be divided into voting blocks in order to reach a majority decision. All of these activities were supervised by the scribe or secretary of the Port, clearly a salaried official." p 84
column170: Regulated by the rules of the constitution. Made up of the elders

column5:
'Cleisthenes reorganized Athens into 139 demes—units of 150 to 250 individuals. In addition to belonging to a deme, citizens were associated with one of ten new artificially created “tribes” that now each sent 50 individuals, selected by lot, to a Council of 500 that would administer the day-to-day affairs of the city.' (p. 32)

From 462 BCE, even the lower classes, thetes, could hold office

'The Greek city-states for the most part failed to establish command-and-control bureaucracies. Nor did the Greek world develop an integrated master social or theological narrative that would have provided ideological support for the necessity of individual obedience to central authority' (Ober, Josiah (2015), p. 60)

'quasi-federal institutional reforms in the aftermath of a democratic revolution (ch. 7). Federalism was widely adopted in mainland Greece in the fourth century BCE (ch. 9). Federalist and quasi-federalist institutional experiments allowed Greek states to operate as extensive “networks of social networks”—and thereby contributed to solving the problem of monitoring and punishing free riders.' (p. 68)

Community rewards to those 'who lead efforts to punish malefactors.' (p. 68)

'Under Cleisthenes’ reformed constitutional order, 139 villages, towns, and neighborhoods of Attica were designated “demes.” An average deme had a free adult male population of 150– ­250, although some were smaller, and others, notably Aphidna and Acharnai, much larger.' (Ober, Josiah (2015), p. 162)

'Each Athenian was thus treated as a citizen at different levels: locally in his deme and at the federal level of the polis. All free adult males resident in Attica in the year of the reform were, in the immediate aftermath of the revolution, considered to be citizens of Athens and of their deme of residence. Moreover, the deme would hereafter be the fundamental unit of Athenian citizenship: To be a citizen of Athens, a male resident of Attica must be formally recognized by an assembly of citizens in his deme as having been born to an Athenian father who was himself a citizen of the deme, and as being at least 18 years of age.' (p. 162-4)

'Two intermediate levels of belonging connected the demes to the federal state. Citizens of each deme were assigned to one of ten newly created artificial “tribes.” Each tribe enrolled roughly a tenth of the citizens, drawn from three distinct regions of Attica.' (p. 164)

'Perhaps most importantly, the membership of the new central state Council of 500, which conducted Athens’ day-­ to-­ day public affairs and set the agenda for the legislative citizen assembly, was recruited through the new deme/tribe system. In later years, at least, councilors were aged 30 and older, were chosen by lot, and were paid for their service. Each of the 10 tribes annually provided 50 councilors. The members of each tribal contingent of 50 were chosen at the deme level, each deme sending a certain number of councilors according to population.' (p. 164)

'But Cleisthenes had not introduced to Athens what we think of today as “representative government” because councilors were not expected to represent the particularistic interests of their deme, regional third, or tribe. Nor were they accountable to local voters. Rather, the councilors served, collectively, as a microcosm of the Athenian citizenry. They represented what, in the aggregate, the Athenian people knew and the skills and information the Athenians could bring to bear on problems confronting the state.' (p. 164)

Areopagus
- 'membership was drawn from ex-­magistrates' (p. 166)

'The Athenian citizenry elected their military leaders; many other state officials were, however, chosen by lottery. All officials, elected or lotteried, were subject to ex ante public scrutiny and held publicly accountable, on an annual basis, for their performance.' (p. 168)

'Each year, the Athenian assembly decided whether to conduct an ostracism; if the decision was positive (as it was only 15 recorded times in Athenian history), the citizenry chose, by plurality written ballot, which prominent member of the Athenian elite to expel from the community for 10 years.' (p. 168)

The Council met almost daily, whilst the Assembly met four times each month

'The Solonian people’s court was subdivided into a number of courts, so that many more cases could now be judged by panels of citizens, chosen by lottery.' (p. 168)

'Federalism enabled trust among citizens, arising from local interactions at the deme level, to be leveraged at the level of the tribe and then at the level of the polis.' (p. 170)

'The deme-­tribe-­polis federal system helped to make the mass meetings of the Athenian assembly both less daunting and less clientalistic, as ordinary citizens developed social networks that extended at least to the tribe level.' (p. 171)

'Athenian citizens proved to be quite good at identifying and attending to experts and quite capable of using the knowledge of experts for the ends of policy-­ making without turning state management over to them.' (p. 172)
column11:
Stasavage, David (2020), The Decline and Rise of Democracy

Ober, Josiah (2015), The Rise and Fall of Classical Greece

'Each year, the Athenian assembly decided whether to conduct an ostracism; if the decision was positive (as it was only 15 recorded times in Athenian history), the citizenry chose, by plurality written ballot, which prominent member of the Athenian elite to expel from the community for 10 years.' (p. 168)

'Cleisthenes reorganized Athens into 139 demes—units of 150 to 250 individuals. In addition to belonging to a deme, citizens were associated with one of ten new artificially created “tribes” that now each sent 50 individuals, selected by lot, to a Council of 500 that would administer the day-to-day affairs of the city.' (p. 32)

From 462 BCE, even the lower classes, thetes, could hold office

'The Greek city-states for the most part failed to establish command-and-control bureaucracies. Nor did the Greek world develop an integrated master social or theological narrative that would have provided ideological support for the necessity of individual obedience to central authority' (Ober, Josiah (2015), p. 60)

'quasi-federal institutional reforms in the aftermath of a democratic revolution (ch. 7). Federalism was widely adopted in mainland Greece in the fourth century BCE (ch. 9). Federalist and quasi-federalist institutional experiments allowed Greek states to operate as extensive “networks of social networks”—and thereby contributed to solving the problem of monitoring and punishing free riders.' (p. 68)

Community rewards to those 'who lead efforts to punish malefactors.' (p. 68)

'Under Cleisthenes’ reformed constitutional order, 139 villages, towns, and neighborhoods of Attica were designated “demes.” An average deme had a free adult male population of 150– ­250, although some were smaller, and others, notably Aphidna and Acharnai, much larger.' (Ober, Josiah (2015), p. 162)

'Each Athenian was thus treated as a citizen at different levels: locally in his deme and at the federal level of the polis. All free adult males resident in Attica in the year of the reform were, in the immediate aftermath of the revolution, considered to be citizens of Athens and of their deme of residence. Moreover, the deme would hereafter be the fundamental unit of Athenian citizenship: To be a citizen of Athens, a male resident of Attica must be formally recognized by an assembly of citizens in his deme as having been born to an Athenian father who was himself a citizen of the deme, and as being at least 18 years of age.' (p. 162-4)

'Two intermediate levels of belonging connected the demes to the federal state. Citizens of each deme were assigned to one of ten newly created artificial “tribes.” Each tribe enrolled roughly a tenth of the citizens, drawn from three distinct regions of Attica.' (p. 164)

'Perhaps most importantly, the membership of the new central state Council of 500, which conducted Athens’ day-­ to-­ day public affairs and set the agenda for the legislative citizen assembly, was recruited through the new deme/tribe system. In later years, at least, councilors were aged 30 and older, were chosen by lot, and were paid for their service. Each of the 10 tribes annually provided 50 councilors. The members of each tribal contingent of 50 were chosen at the deme level, each deme sending a certain number of councilors according to population.' (p. 164)

'But Cleisthenes had not introduced to Athens what we think of today as “representative government” because councilors were not expected to represent the particularistic interests of their deme, regional third, or tribe. Nor were they accountable to local voters. Rather, the councilors served, collectively, as a microcosm of the Athenian citizenry. They represented what, in the aggregate, the Athenian people knew and the skills and information the Athenians could bring to bear on problems confronting the state.' (p. 164)

- 'membership was drawn from ex-­magistrates' (p. 166)

'The Athenian citizenry elected their military leaders; many other state officials were, however, chosen by lottery. All officials, elected or lotteried, were subject to ex ante public scrutiny and held publicly accountable, on an annual basis, for their performance.' (p. 168)

'Each year, the Athenian assembly decided whether to conduct an ostracism; if the decision was positive (as it was only 15 recorded times in Athenian history), the citizenry chose, by plurality written ballot, which prominent member of the Athenian elite to expel from the community for 10 years.' (p. 168)

'The Solonian people’s court was subdivided into a number of courts, so that many more cases could now be judged by panels of citizens, chosen by lottery.' (p. 168)

'Federalism enabled trust among citizens, arising from local interactions at the deme level, to be leveraged at the level of the tribe and then at the level of the polis.' (p. 170)

'The deme-­tribe-­polis federal system helped to make the mass meetings of the Athenian assembly both less daunting and less clientalistic, as ordinary citizens developed social networks that extended at least to the tribe level.' (p. 171)

'Athenian citizens proved to be quite good at identifying and attending to experts and quite capable of using the knowledge of experts for the ends of policy-­ making without turning state management over to them.' (p. 172)

column169: Magistrates of the city, duties range from financial to military to administrative. Some are selected by lot, some are elected. we have evidence for at least 71 boards (Hansen, ADAD, 239). were probably paid in the 5th century but pay was discontinued in the 4th (ibid. 240-1)
column170: implement decisions of the other bodies

column5:
BOUNDARY CASE: there is a council but degree  of independence for the king is not clear. Compare with Tlaxcala, a city state under the Aztecs, but more independent.

 110 city-states, 50 in the Valley of Mexico and 60 in Morelos. size and population varied. 

Each city-state was headed by a king and governed by a hereditary nobility

“One unusual aspect of city-state government was the existence of polities with more than one king operating at a single city: recorded cases have two or four kings." However, these should not be seen as polities governed by multiple kings. instead, they are different polities which shared a common urban center. p. 589
column11: Michael E. Smith, Aztec City-States, in Hansen, A Comparative Study of Thirty City-States Cultures
column169: King, chosen among the male members of the royal dynasty by a council of high nobles. heredity and (military) meritocracy determine selection. succession is usually father to son or brother to brother

column169: Able to choose the king from male members of the royal dynasty. They organised various aspects of the city-state government. They were judges, tribute collectors, high-ranking military officials and general royal advisors.

column3: Leader (first among equals),Assembly (central),Checks and balances,Consent,Mandate,Council (central)
column5:
The city-states of southern Mesopotamia in the period under consideration maintain local forms of collective governance under the Assyrian empire. 

"our understanding of the exact functions of the assembly and the elders is complicated by the many civil administrative systems that existed at imperial, provincial and city level. Furthermore, these bodies interlock with the bureaucracy of the central temple institutions to form an intricate judicial apparatus that developed over time and varied from place to place." Barjamovic 2004, 67

"the ‘governors’ appointed to the Babylonian city-states
(not to the regional provinces) were almost all of local origin, and they did not share the high status of the Assyrian bel pahutu. Instead, it seems their main function, regardless
of where they were presiding, was to represent the city toward the king and his officials, and to act as a link between the political institutions of the city-state and the empire." Barjamovic 2004, p. 54
column11:
Larsen, The City-States of the Early Neo-Babylonian Period, in Hansen, A Comparative Study of Thirty City-States Cultures

Barjamovic 2004, CIVIC INSTITUTIONS AND SELF-GOVERNMENT IN SOUTHERN
MESOPOTAMIA IN THE MID-FIRST MILLENNIUM BC.
column169: Governor of the city-state
column170: Appointed and controlled by the central administration.

column169:
A civic institution that holds authority on behalf of the
community and bears its name (Barjamovic 2004, p. 56). Interchangeably used with "the assembly". Functions may have included choosing governors, waging war, directing foreign policy, exercising legal functions, control funds for public works and cultic functions.

column3: Autocratic Leader/Chief (bound),Blood relations,Tribunal/Court ,Suspension/Expulsion/Ostracism/Proscription,Assembly (central),Council (central)
column5:
'While it is true that Carthage had a range of administrative bodies within which affairs of state could be debated at length, decisions were mainly the prerogative of the wealthiest families. Later on there was a kind of representative body that was able to enforce its will in certain issues, for instance regarding the appointment of military leaders, but there was probably no democratic governance with voting rights for the population.' (p. 14)

'The priesthood in Carthage was reserved for males of the aristocracy and was hereditary. The chief of the priests or rab kohanim, besides his important religious role, also exercised great influence over the workings of the State and economic life' (p. 41)

'Although the monarchy was certainly not hereditary, the most important positions were reserved for the members of certain families, which had the effect of creating dynasties.' (p. 42)

In the 4th ce. BC, Carthage became an aristocratic republic with a king, the 'Council of Elders' (similar to the Roman senate), the 'Tribunal of 104', and the 'ham', a parliamentary assembly

'From the late fourth century BC onwards, Carthage was governed by two annually–elected suffetes, similar to Roman consuls, and the parliamentary assembly also appears to have increased in importance.' (p. 42)

Population numbers: "This urban region would have had a population of 5,000 to 8,000 in the seventh century BC, which is very large in the context of ancient civilisations. By the second century BC this figure had grown to at least 50,000, if not 100,000, and even 300,000 is mentioned." (p.30)

From Lancel, Carthage, A History
Aristotle famously attributed to 4th Carthage a mixed constitution. a century later, Polybius documents a shift toward popular rule (a debasement from the oligarchic constitution of Aristotle's time)
column11: Docter, Roald (2015), Punic Carthage, in Carthage Fact and Myth. Sidestone Press.
column169:
Chief priest
'besides his important religious role, also exercised great influence over the workings of the State and economic life' (p. 41)

'From the late fourth century BC onwards, Carthage was governed by two annually–elected suffetes, similar to Roman consuls, and the parliamentary assembly also appears to have increased in importance.' (p. 42)

Population numbers: "This urban region would have had a population of 5,000 to 8,000 in the seventh century BC, which is very large in the context of ancient civilisations. By the second century BC this figure had grown to at least 50,000, if not 100,000, and even 300,000 is mentioned." (p.30)

From Lancel, Carthage, A History
Aristotle famously attributed to 4th Carthage a mixed constitution. a century later, Polybius documents a shift toward popular rule (a debasement from the oligarchic constitution of Aristotle's time)
column11: Docter, Roald (2015), Punic Carthage, in Carthage Fact and Myth. Sidestone Press.

column5:
'While it is true that Carthage had a range of administrative bodies within which affairs of state could be debated at length, decisions were mainly the prerogative of the wealthiest families. Later on there was a kind of representative body that was able to enforce its will in certain issues, for instance regarding the appointment of military leaders, but there was probably no democratic governance with voting rights for the population.' (p. 14)

'The priesthood in Carthage was reserved for males of the aristocracy and was hereditary. The chief of the priests or rab kohanim, besides his important religious role, also exercised great influence over the workings of the State and economic life' (p. 41)

'Although the monarchy was certainly not hereditary, the most important positions were reserved for the members of certain families, which had the effect of creating dynasties.' (p. 42)

In the 4th ce. BC, Carthage became an aristocratic republic with a king, the 'Council of Elders' (similar to the Roman senate), the 'Tribunal of 104', and the 'ham', a parliamentary assembly

'From the late fourth century BC onwards, Carthage was governed by two annually–elected suffetes, similar to Roman consuls, and the parliamentary assembly also appears to have increased in importance.' (p. 42)

Population numbers: "This urban region would have had a population of 5,000 to 8,000 in the seventh century BC, which is very large in the context of ancient civilisations. By the second century BC this figure had grown to at least 50,000, if not 100,000, and even 300,000 is mentioned." (p.30)

From Lancel, Carthage, A History
Aristotle famously attributed to 4th Carthage a mixed constitution. a century later, Polybius documents a shift toward popular rule (a debasement from the oligarchic constitution of Aristotle's time)

column3: Leader (first among equals),Heredity,Matrilineality,Consent,Council (local),Payment for occupying office,Reputational risk,Alliance,Representation,Meritocracy
column5:
Villages spread across a large region. Political organization varies by area (North-east has collective governance vs. West has leaders)

Political org. in the NE (p. 226-234)

The villages are headed by a big man who acts as a primus inter pares

Several villages constitute a vicinage, which is ruled collectively by representatives of the founding matrilineages in a council 

The council is composed of the members of the highest rank of the ngongo munene, a sodality that includes several ranks
-	The lower ranks are open to all men
-	The higher are occupied by heredity, reputation, and the paying of large fees

A female equivalent exercised authority over women but we know too little about the organization (dual-sex?)

Vicinages come together in alliances 

Professional hunters come together in a buyanga, an association that crosses several vicinages (elite club)

Excerpts: 
'He was therefore the de facto leader of the village, or at least a primus inter pares. He had direct control over all the marriages of the girls of his settlement, which is an indication of the ﬁerce competition for members between big men and their respective Houses or villages.' (p. 230)

'The vicinage was ruled collectively from a designated special place by representatives of those matrilineages thought to have ﬁrst settled on the land and to which the leaders of each House in the vicinage belonged. Both the grouping of such founding lineages and the place of their meeting were called ekuluwandá 9/6 , an expression which contains the notion of ngandá 9/10, a notion that designated all the inhabitants of the vicinage and is best translated as “society.”' (p. 230)

'Ekuluwandá, then, is the “place of the elders of the society.” This collective government was exercised on behalf of all the constituent settlements and of all age-related initiation groups. It was expressed through the performances of the sodality called ngongo munene or “great territory.” This sodality included three or four ranked levels complete with a hierarchy of masks marked in diﬀerent ways to indicate their rank. Induction into the initial rank of the association was voluntary, collective, and open to all adult men. Accession to higher ranks was, in part, hereditary in that it had to be patriﬁlial but descent was not enough. Candidates had to have the approval of the members of the rank they wanted to join, and they had to pay a hefty entrance fee.' (p. 231)

'Government was exercised by members of the highest rank of the ngongo munene. These were the mutúmbú 3/4 who decreed the necessary measures for all collective endeavors from organizing collective hunts to initiations, war, and the adjudication of all court cases.' (p. 231)

'The female equivalent of the ngongo munene exercised authority over women with regard to issues concerning them, but data are sorely lacking concerning their ruling organization.' (p. 232)

'in the late nineteenth century and undoubtedly also in earlier times, details of its institutions diﬀered from district to district. In some places, there were four ranks of the governing association and in others only three; in some places, such as among the Sala Mpasu, individual big men held more power than the ruling sodality, while in other places the balance of power tilted in favor of the sodality, as among the Kongo-Dinga.' (p. 233)

- 'Still, in essence, it remained the same system: everywhere society was structured by a hierarchy of age-sets and governed collectively by an oligarchy.' (p. 233)

Political org. in the WEST (p. 234 –244)

'While people in the northeast of the region developed collective governance, their neighbors to the west took a slightly diﬀerent path by choosing to strengthen the authority of individual leaders in villages and vicinages without enlarging the scale of governance much beyond that of a vicinage.' (p. 234)

'Frictions between villages, especially within the same vicinage, were settled by arbitration through common palavers in a thoroughly decentralized manner. In these assemblies, “speakers” (ngambi 9/10) for each matrilineage set out their positions, and decisions were reached by a consensus of the whole audience.' (p. 237)

- 'Ngambi were “big men.” They were chosen within each lineage for their wealth plus oratory talent and they enjoyed a status marked by special privileges and customs. 88 They also formed a sort of club or guild that transcended individual vicinages. The institutions of the palaver and the ngambi were the main overarching institutions that tied the villages of a vicinage together and which settled serious conﬂicts between neighboring vicinages.' (p. 237)

'Lwimbi 'decided to appoint their chiefs for a limited period of time only. Chiefs were installed ﬁrst for two years and could then be reconﬁrmed for a total of six or maximum of eight years.' (p. 247)



Population numbers Vansina p, 189: size of chiefdoms varies significantly but roughly within the range indicated here.
column6:
10th -15th century AD
(start date is arbitrary, period is pre-colonial)
column11:
Vansina, Jan (2004), How Societies Are Born: Governance in West Central Africa before 1600

Stasavage, David (2020), The Decline and Rise of Democracy

column3: Meritocracy,Oath,Military force,Remunerated position,Magistrate/official,Mediation,Rule of Law,Consultation,Screening process,Heredity,Public meetings,Assembly (central),Leader (first among equals),Consensus
column5:
Period of small cities (sometimes reunited under larger states) that enjoyed a great degree of independence, even though still ruled under one King and an elite. “Cities were physically divided into separate districts devoted to political and religious activities, artisan workshops, and residences. (…) The population was divided into at least three major social groupings: nobles, free citizens, and a non-free group consisting of slaves and aliens. ” (Lewis in Hansen, 359). A great degree of spirituality is still present, as a remainder from ancient times of a fallen theocracy.

Tin-bor Hui (in Edinburgh Companion to the history of democracy) assesses the emergence of rights during the warring periods but offers little contribution to institutional structures
column11:
Stasavage, David (2020), The Decline and Rise of Democracy, 149-152

Lewis, Mark Edward (1999), Warring States Political History in The Cambridge History of Ancient China, 597-650

Lewis, Mark Edward (2000), The City-State in Spring-and-Autumn China in A Comparative Study of Thirty City-State Cultures, 359-373

Further consulted Tin-bor Hui in Edinburgh Companion to the history of democracy
column169:
Popular Assembly

"Though not regularized, there are numerous examples of important occasions where rulers consulted with the assembled guo ren" (Stasavage 2020, 150)

guo ren means citizens (Mark Edward Lewis in Hansen and in Cambridge History). The assembly was not regularly summoned, but frequently and it helped the ruler to take important decisions. Nobles participated as well, but it was not elite.

as struggle between rival nobles intensified, the assembly came to 
play a more crucial role in civil conflict. although there is no evidence for the citizens controlling the government, their support was crucial to anyone who sought to govern (Lewis p. 369)
column170: They helped the rulers make decisions

column169: Hierarchy titles (ranks) to reward meritorious service to the state, particularly military success. These ranks entailed certain legal and religious privileges.

column3: Meritocracy,Oath,Military force,Remunerated position,Magistrate/official,Mediation,Rule of Law,Consultation,Screening process,Heredity,Public meetings,Assembly (central),Leader (first among equals),Consensus
column5:
Period of small cities (sometimes reunited under larger states) that enjoyed a great degree of independence, even though still ruled under one King and an elite. “Cities were physically divided into separate districts devoted to political and religious activities, artisan workshops, and residences. (…) The population was divided into at least three major social groupings: nobles, free citizens, and a non-free group consisting of slaves and aliens. ” (Lewis in Hansen, 359). A great degree of spirituality is still present, as a remainder from ancient times of a fallen theocracy.

Tin-bor Hui (in Edinburgh Companion to the history of democracy) assesses the emergence of rights during the warring periods but offers little contribution to institutional structures

column169:
Directly administered districts in the state of Qin, with a magistrate (ling), vice-magistrate (cheng), a military commandant (wei) and sefu (overseers). 

Later called jun (with expansion), but later subdivided again into xian, thus creating a two-tiered system of administration.
column170: Include a ling, a cheng, wei and sefus.

column169:
Not an indispensable element of the new state structure, neither active participants in the political world. They evolved in close relation with the states of the period

"The first Emperor kept a large number of broadly learned official scholars (boshi) at his court"
Usually selling their services to clerks and ritual specialists, occasionally to royal courts but more often to great families, the courts of lesser states, or the households of newly enfeoffed nobles.
column170: They were advisers to the ruler, given their “broadly learned” status.

column169: Nobility ruling the Warring States. It includes kings, feudal lords hereditary ministers and nobles. Offices are hereditary, ruler is first among equals, decisions require consensus  - at least in theory (Lewis, p. 368). Authority is best understood as being wielded collectively.
column170: Composed by king, feudal lord, hereditary minister and nobles

column3: Council (central) ,Gerontocracy,Matriarchy
column5:
'female warriors played a direct—even dominant—role in government.' (Stasavage, David, p. 58)

'In the olden times, there was the Council of the Matriarchs, which was made up of wise and far-sighted mature ladies. The Council discussed the day-to- day issues of the young Narts, and legislated laws and customs according to which the youth had to abide in their mundane life. The Council members relied on their long experience and perspicacity in formulating relevant edicts' (Jaimoukha (2001), p. 165)

same passage also cited in Maxime Kovalevsky ‘La famille matriarcale au Caucase’, in L’Anthropologie, vol. 4, 1893, pp 259- 78. There is no additional info on this council. in any of the sources.
column11:
Stasavage, David (2020), The Decline and Rise of Democracy, pp. 58-9.

Jaimoukha, Amjad (2001), The Circassians: A Handbook
column169: 'In the olden times, there was the Council of the Matriarchs, which was made up of wise and far-sighted mature ladies. The Council discussed the day-to- day issues of the young Narts, and legislated laws and customs according to which the youth had to abide in their mundane life. The Council members relied on their long experience and perspicacity in formulating relevant edicts' (Jaimoukha (2001), p. 165)

column3: Co-optation,Voting,Election,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Council (central)
column5:
Merchant oligarchy. Focus on the 12-13th centuries, after which there are constitutional changes that do not significantly alter the power structure.

'Cologne’s leading patrician families had established de facto political control by the thirteenth century, the outcome of a dispute with Cologne’s archbishop' (Stasavage, States of Credit, p. 166, EPUB version)

'City finances were managed by the city council, which in turn relied on a chief financial official known as the rentmeister, as well as managers of three separate annuity chambers (rentkammern) or treasuries: the Wednesday Chamber, the Friday Chamber, and the Saturday Chamber' (p. 168)

'Beginning in 1216 formal authority in Cologne was exercised by the city council. This was a small body of fifteen members that was renewed each year and for which the fifteen new members of the incoming council were chosen by the outgoing council—a system of cooptation.' 'this selection mechanism ensured that control of the council remained with a small number of influential families' (p. 171)

Constitutional change: "The popular revolt in 1396 led to the creation of a new constitution, the Verbundbrief , which was designed to ensure broader representation in Cologne’s governance. As a result of the 1396 reform... the selection method for the city council was altered. Political organization in the city was now to be based on 22 individual corporations, or Gaffel. Five of these were associations of merchants, and the remaining seventeen were designed to represent Cologne’s numerous craft guilds. The Gaffel in turn elected 36 of the 49 members of a new city council. The remaining thirteen members were to be selected by the first thirty-six.' (p. 171)

The new constitution does not alter the power structure: 
'while the Gaffel now elected thirty-six of the forty-nine council members, the heads of each Gaffel were not themselves chosen in an open election by all members—they were instead selected by a special committee of more prominent members'

Population numbers: 40000 (source: Johanek's chapter in Hansens' collection of 30 city-states)
column11: Stasavage, David (2011), States of credit: size, power, and the development of European polities, EPUB version

As a result of the 1396 reform... the selection method for the city council was altered. Political organization in the city was now to be based on 22 individual corporations, or Gaffel. Five of these were associations of merchants, and the remaining seventeen were designed to represent Cologne’s numerous craft guilds. The Gaffel in turn elected 36 of the 49 members of a new city council. The remaining thirteen members were to be selected by the first thirty-six.' (p. 171)

The new constitution does not alter the power structure: 
'while the Gaffel now elected thirty-six of the forty-nine council members, the heads of each Gaffel were not themselves chosen in an open election by all members—they were instead selected by a special committee of more prominent members'

Population numbers: 40000 (source: Johanek's chapter in Hansens' collection of 30 city-states)
column11: Stasavage, David (2011), States of credit: size, power, and the development of European polities, EPUB version
column169:

column5:
Municipal self-governance under a monarch responsible for fiscal, trade and military functions. To be distinguished from (later) independent city-states and free cities in Italy and Germany.

Contrary to previous scholarship, Reynolds advocates for a similarity of social and political institutions across Europe (p. 7-8)

"Early medieval government, then, was in its own way both
constitutional and representative: constitutional because
kings were supposed to be limited by law, custom and consultation; and representative, firstly because the king made
and declared law as the supreme representative of his people,
and secondly because those with whom he was supposed to
consult were themselves representative. The bishops and
nobles of a kingdom, like the senior and richer landowners of
a province or village, were, in the terms of the time, those
who were qualified to speak on behalf of the collectivity of
which they were the most solid, respectable, and responsible
members." p. 22

CH 1: LAW
Like in anglo saxon England, "assemblies" dealt with legal and legislative matters. In the communes, assemblies' judicial functions included judgment as well as arbitration and mediation. (p. 25)

Assemblies were presided by a president, either the king himself or a representative. Judges could be elites (scabini), iudices, or laymen, and could be appointed by the president or include all the present. Variation depended on the circumstances of the case.

Collective judgment did not apply to unfree peasants (judged by their lord) and cases in which a single judge is in charge (possibly, for more esoteric judgment having to do with roman law). (p 31-2)

judgments were sworn (p.33)

Evolution over time: "There can be no doubt that the twelfth and thirteenth centuries began to bring important changes to the ideas and practices of law. The strengthening of government began to transform the law by emphasizing one source of its authority and enforcement among others. More and more crimes came to incur formal punishments, inflicted by the authority of the ruler, instead of being left to mutual negotiation by feud and wergeld. Although in practice the maintenance of law and order still depended in large measure on collective self-policing, it was now the king’s (or sometimes the count’s or duke’s) peace which the law-breaker broke. The old amorphous assemblies were replaced by something more like modern law-courts, working within something more like
defined jurisdictions, and these gradually began to be organized into hierarchies of superior and inferior authority.’ Meanwhile the keeping of records reduced the flexibility of
custom at the same time that the increasing pace of secular
legislation, combined with religious reform and the extension
of papal jurisdiction, started to cast doubt on its inherent
validity. (p. 39)

CH 6 URBAN POLITICS
Assemblies were a fact of life (p. 164), likely to be meeting regularly (p. 167). 

The chapter focuses overwhelmingly on the later period and on cities already present in the database either individually (like Pisa, Genoa, Venice etc) or as a group (imperial and free town of the holy roman empire). Whereas forms of autonomous governance also continued both in France (local mayors) and England (see entry for anglo-saxon England), monarchical presence seems to have been stronger here than in italy and germany. (p. 178-180)

A generic account of political institutions in independent cities is provided on pp. 188-196, summarized as follows: "vocabularies differed, and so did the degree of complexity, but the framework of councils and offices, rotating part-time service, assemblies, elections, and audits was very much the same. 

Population numbers drawn (by FC) by comparison with other European cases in the same period.
column11: Reynolds, Kingdoms and communities in Western Europe, 900-1300

column3: Assembly (central),Confederacy,Turnover/rotation,Representation,Voting,Frequent and/or regular meetings,Majority voting,Assembly (local),Agenda setting,Co-optation,Magistrate/official,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Council (local),Life appointment
column5:
Federation of 7 provinces, representing 57 towns, each of which had population numbers from 1000 to 10000.

Governing organs at the federal level included: 
- States-General, an assembly comprising representatives of each of the seven provinces (each has one vote aiming at unanimity in theory but often using majority {cf. Israel p. 276), rotating presidency with one province chairing meetings for one week at a time)
- Council of State, the executive of the States General

Governing organs in each state varied but included (from Israel):
- A provincial assembly, representing the towns (but only some could vote)
- a standing committee, setting the agenda

AS FOR TOWN GOVERNANCE, it included:
- a permanent council (vroedschap) - cooptive and whose members had life appointments
- magistrates

An in-depth account of provincial Dutch institutions is in ch. 13 of Israel's book (see references)

column169:
Permanent council in the towns of the west, constituting the core of local government. The council was cooptive and its members had an appointment for life. Major policy decisions were discussed, and it was convened regularly. 
”From the ranks of the councillors the aldermen and mayors were recruited. The seven, nine, or eleven aldermen were the local court of justice. The majors, two or four of whom were always serving simultaneously, were the executive. Together, the aldermen and mayors constituted the magistracy, that acted as the legislative authority, in its own right or in conjunction with the council.”
column170: Top governance institution in towns in the West

column169:
Composed of aldermen and mayors. 

Selection differs in the east and west:
- west: Magistrates are recruited from the councillors, appointment is temporary and limited to 2/3 years at a stretch. usually magistrates are reelected and in the meantime they go back to the council

- east: magistrates who lost their seat were politically side-tracked. Many magistrates were elected through a procedure that involved the local community.
column170: top governance institution in towns in the East

column169: Entitled to appoint aldermen, and even the mayors. In this process, towns were entitled to propose candidates on a so-called double list, that restricted the choice for the stadholder and allowed the towns to manipulate the process. In practice, the stadholder picked one or two local confidants, who would make sure that the right people were on the list.
column170: Appointing aldermen and mayors (everywhere in Netherlands).

Minister, Head of the "lugal council."

Functions: army general, head of the palatial administration, tax collector, overseer of merchants.

Emerges late, roughly in the last 20 years in the period under consideration. Eventually, it becomes an hereditary position. "The figure of the minister (O) apparently emerged as a sort of 'primus inter pares' within the council of the lugals, and gained preeminence during the reigns of the last two kings of Ebla, when the position of minister became a de fact hereditary role." Benati, 40.

column5:
Entry focuses on the middle kingdom, when we have most clear evidence of the presence of both councils, the Qenbet and Djadjat (but the same organization probably applies to all periods).

Pharaoh relied heavily on his advisors when making decisions. As such, Royal Court had high enough authority to impose corporal punishments. Vizier, acting as Pharaoh's deputy, oversaw the administration of the Royal Court and partook in the decision-making process. Royal Court itself was heavily bureaucratic just like Egypt in general and was divided into various departments such as treasury, police, district, and each department had its main overseer who had to answer to Vizier. To ensure Vizier's informedness there was an institution of 'Hearers' who acted as the system of bureaucratic control. 

There were also local Pharaoh's administrations around Egypt run by the Herald, who informed Pharaoh of people's aspirations and acted as pharaoh's mouthpiece.

For local decision-making and legal proceedings there were two councils - Djadjat and Qenbet. Djadjat was the dominant council in the Old and Middle Kingdoms, and Qenbet was dominant in the New Kingdom. However, they both did exist during all three kingdoms just with varying levels of importance. From the readings, I got the impression that Qenbet was more concerned with local justice and Djadjat with local governance. They were run by local notables such as Mayors and Priests.


A story about the 'Eloquent Peasant' that shows the Egyptian Institution of Petitioning:

----- BACKSTORY OF ROBBERY -----
p. 1
“There was a man called Khunanup. He was a peasant of the Wadi Natrun and he had a wife called Meret”
“This peasant said to his wife of his: ‘Look, I am going to Egypt to fetch provisions there for my children’”
p. 3
“[???]”
p. 5
“He [peasant] came across a man”
“His name was Nemtinakht and he was the son of a man called Isry”
“These were liegemen of the high steward Rensi, son of Meru”
“And the Nemitinakht said, when he saw the donkeys of this peasant, which were desirable to his heart:”
p. 6
“‘Would that I had some divine image with which I could rob the good of this peasant!”
“Now, the house of the Nemtinakht was at a waterside path that was narrow, it was not broad: it measured the width of a loincloth. Its one side was under water, the other=er under barley.”
“This Nemtinankht then said to a servant of his:”
p. 7
“’Hurry, and bring me a cape from my house!’”
“Then he spread it out on the waterside path, so that its hem came to rest on water, and its selvage on the barley.”
“And this peasant came on the public path”
“This Nemtinakht then said: ‘Beware, peasant, you will not step on my clothes!”
p. 8
“And the peasant said: ‘I shall do what you wish; my way is good.’”
“And he went up higher. Then this Nemtinakht said: ‘Is my Upper-Egyptian barley to be a path for you?’”
“And this peasant said: ‘My ways are good; the bank is steep, and the ways are under barley for you block our path with your clothes!’”
p. 9
“’Will you then not allow us to pass on the path?’”
“As he had finished saying […] words, then one of the donkeys filled its mouth with a wisp of barley.”
“And this Nemtinakht said: ‘But look, your donkey is eating my barley!”
p. 10
… “I will buy my donkey for 10 times the value”
“Now, I know the lord of this district; it belongs to the high steward Rensi, son of Meru. He is the one who restrains every thief in this entire land.”
“Shall I now be robbed in his district?”
p. 11
…
“Then, he [Nemtinakht] took a rod of fresh tamarisk to him, and he thrashed all his [peasant’s] limbs with it, took his donkey away and drove them to his district”

----- STORY OF PETITIONING -----
p. 13
“Then this peasant spent a period of 10 days pleading with this Nemtinakht, but he did not pay attention to it.”
“This peasant then went to Herakleopolis in order to plead with the high steward Rensi, son of Meru”
p. 14
“He [peasant] found him [high steward Rensi] emerging from the door of his house, to step into his official boat.”
“And this peasant said: ‘May I be allowed to inform you about this grievance. Perhaps one may have a servant of your choice come to me, so that I may have him report to you about it.’”
p. 15-16
“And the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, had a servant of his choice go to him, and this peasant had him report back about this entire matter.”
“Then the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, accused the Nemitinakht to the officials who were with him.”
“But then they said to him: ‘Perhaps it is a peasant of his who went to someone else behind him. Look, that is what they do to peasants of theirs who have gone to others beside them. That is what they do. Is this a cause for punishing this Nemtinakht, on account of I little natron and a little salt? If he is ordered to replace it, then he will replace it.’”
p. 16
“But the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, remained silent.”
p. 17
“He did not answer these officials, nor did he answer this peasant.”
“Then this peasant came to pleas with him”
p. 21
“The high steward Rensi, son of Meru, then went before His Majesty and said: ‘My lord, I have found one of these peasants who is truly eloquent. By a man who is my peer. His goods have been robbed. He has come to please with me about it.’”
p. 22-23
“And His Majesty said: ‘As you wish to see me in health, you will delay him here without answering anything he says. So that he keeps speaking, remain silent. So that his speech will be brought to us in writing. So that we may hear it. But provide sustenance for the wife and children of this peasant. That one of these peasants comes here is because his house is empty. […] Furthermore, provide sustenance for this peasant himself. You will let the provisions be given to him without letting him know.’”
p. 24
“They were given to friends of his and his friends gave them to him.”
“Then the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, sent a message to the mayor of the Wadi Natrun about making provisions for the wife of this peasant.”
p. 36
“And the peasant came to plead with him for a third time”
P. 44
“When this peasant had said these words, the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, went to the entrance of the portal…”
p. 45
“…and made two guards turn against him with whips, and they thrashed all his limbs therewith”
p. 54
“You were appointed to hear cases, to judge between litigants and to punish the robber”
“But look, what you are doing is supporting the thief”
p. 59
“…and your environment is corrupt. And every man in your environment is corrupt”
p. 60
“High steward, my lord, you are the helm of the entire land, the land sails in accordance with your command. You are the equal of Thoth, who judges without being partial.”
p. 64
“Yet officials should be people who dispel injustice, lords of goodness, craftsmen in creating what is, people who men a severed head.”
p. 71
“And this peasant came to plead with him for a ninth time”
p. 76
“Look, I am pleading with you but you do not hear it.”
“I will go and plead concerning you with Anubis.”
“Then, the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, sent two guards to bring him back”
…
p. 77
“Then the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, said: ‘Don’t be afraid, peasant! Look, you will arrange the matter with me’” …
p. 78
“The high steward Rensi, son of Meru, said: ‘Now wait here and hear your petitions!’ And from a new papyrus roll he had every petition read out according to [its] content”
“Then the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, delivered them to the majesty of the king of Upper and Lower Egypt Nebkaure, justified and they pleased his heart more than anything in his entire land.”
p. 79
“Then His Majesty said: ‘Pass judgement yourself, son of Meru!’
“And the high steward Rensi, son of Meru, sent two guards to [fetch Nemtinakht] Then he was brought and inventory was made of”
p. 80
“this Nemitankht […] to this peasant […] […] […] all his”

column169:
The main royal leader of Egypt.

- In Egyptian wisdom literature addressing the subject of kingship: the so-called Teaching for King Merikare (c. 1900BCE). The narrator, himself apparently a king, gives the following advice to a future ruler: 
- "Ensure that you are followed on account of your good character. Contemptible is he who forcefully binds the land to himself." (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- This highlighting of the need to govern on the basis of popular support rather than brute force is then further elaborated on with specific reference to a conciliar form of government :
- "Great is the great man whose great men are great, strong is the king who has councillors, wealthy is he who is rich in his nobles." (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Moreover, in order to extract the most from his relationship with these influential subordinates, Pharaoh is advised to:
- "Be skilled in speech, hence being strong, for the power of a king is his tongue. Speech is mightier than any combat." (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- In these lines, the text expresses a fundamental truth about the nature of pharaonic government: while Pharaoh held office by divine right, the authority vested in the office was at its most effective only when Pharaoh ruled by consent, taking appropriate counsel and using powers of verbal persuasion to justify executive action. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- This chapter will consider the ways in which political discussions of this sort could take place, first by explicitly addressing the relationship between Pharaoh and his entourage, and subsequently moving on to explore other types of assemblies with capacity for decision-making. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
 - ... such texts, while varied in the events they describe, all conform to a fairly rigid overarching structure: Pharaoh announces a major undertaking, he discusses it with his courtiers, and the decision stemming therefrom then leads to Pharaoh’s triumph and the glory of Egypt. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- In a similar vein, a military inscription of Ramesses II also reveals a process of collective decision-making (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Thus, as a result of consultation with his subjects, Pharaoh could make decisions with important military and diplomatic consequences. (Alex Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- However, discussion was by no means limited to military matters and foreign affairs. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- For instance, the Prophecy of Neferti (c. 2000BCE), a narrative about a wise Pharaoh who invites a sage to tell him the future of the realm, starts with a description of routine business at the royal court. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- The impression given here is that Pharaoh held daily audiences with his assembled courtiers, and that the aim of this extended beyond simply being a ceremonial affirmation of royal power. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- In this example, Pharaoh is struck by an idea after the initial audience, and so calls the courtiers back for advice – which serves as the narrative device leading to the sage being invited. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- In another example, now known as the Building Inscription of Senusret I (c. 1950BCE), Pharaoh consults his courtiers before ordering a major construction project. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Likewise, discussion with courtiers seems to have also been required when Pharaoh was dealing with family matters – perhaps because of the potential implications this might have for the royal succession. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Thus, again the Pharaoh is shown to be conducting affairs of state with the assent of those around him. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Part of the story [Tale of Sinuhe (c. 2000BCE)] involves an Egyptian living abroad discussing the mechanisms by which Pharaoh rules Egypt, it being said that :
- "He is the lord of graciousness, great of sweetness – he conquers by love. His city loves him more than its own self, and they rejoice for him more than for (any) god of theirs. The husbands and wives delight in him."  (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Overall, the examples above therefore reveal that inclusive governance was present even at the very apex of political power in Ancient Egypt, it often being ingrained into the decision-making process of Pharaoh himself. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Given the limited nature of the evidence, it remains difficult to determine whether such consultation actually carried decisive political weight or served predominantly as a symbolic act of popular affirmation of predetermined royal policy. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
- Nonetheless, its very presence is highly significant, pointing to a clear need for Pharaoh to consult his people to generate legitimacy. (Alex Loktionov, Inclusive Governance in Ancient Egypt)
